clues: This city is home to a famous tower that sparkles every night.
Known as the 'City of Love' and a hub for fashion and art.
fun_fact: The Eiffel Tower was supposed to be dismantled after 20 years but was saved because it was useful for radio transmissions!
Paris has only one stop sign in the entire city—most intersections rely on priority-to-the-right rules.
trivia: This city is famous for its croissants and macarons. Bon appétit!
Paris was originally a Roman city called Lutetia.

clues: This city has the busiest pedestrian crossing in the world.
You can visit an entire district dedicated to anime, manga, and gaming.
fun_fact: Tokyo was originally a small fishing village called Edo before becoming the bustling capital it is today!
More than 14 million people live in Tokyo, making it one of the most populous cities in the world.
trivia: The city has over 160,000 restaurants, more than any other city in the world.
Tokyo’s subway system is so efficient that train delays of just a few minutes come with formal apologies.

clues: Home to a green statue gifted by France in the 1800s.
Nicknamed 'The Big Apple' and known for its Broadway theaters.
fun_fact: The Statue of Liberty was originally a copper color before oxidizing to its iconic green patina.
Times Square was once called Longacre Square before being renamed in 1904.
trivia: New York City has 468 subway stations, making it one of the most complex transit systems in the world.
The Empire State Building has its own zip code: 10118.

clues: This city is home to a famous clock tower known as Big Ben.
The River Thames flows through this historic capital.
fun_fact: London has over 170 museums, many of which are free to enter.
The London Underground is the oldest metro system in the world, opened in 1863.
trivia: The city has hosted the Olympics three times: 1908, 1948, and 2012.
London's black cabs are required to memorize over 25,000 streets to get their license.

clues: This city is famous for its opera house with a sail-like design.
Home to one of the world's largest natural harbors.
fun_fact: Sydney was the site of the first British colony in Australia, established in 1788.
The Sydney Harbour Bridge is nicknamed 'The Coathanger' due to its arch-based design.
trivia: Bondi Beach in Sydney is one of the most famous surf spots globally.
Sydney's Royal Botanic Garden is home to over 7,500 species of plants.

clues: This city is known for its massive Christ the Redeemer statue.
Famous for its vibrant Carnival festival.
fun_fact: Rio's name means 'River of January' in Portuguese.
The city was once the capital of Portugal, making it the only European capital outside Europe.
trivia: Sugarloaf Mountain offers panoramic views of the city and its beaches.
The Maracanã Stadium in Rio once held nearly 200,000 spectators during a football match.

clues: This city is overlooked by the flat-topped Table Mountain.
Known for its harbor and as a gateway to Robben Island.
fun_fact: Cape Town was the first city outside Europe to get its own castle, the Castle of Good Hope.

trivia: Cape Town's Kirstenbosch Botanical Garden is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
The city has a colony of African penguins at Boulders Beach.

clues: This city features the colorful domes of St. Basil's Cathedral.

trivia: Moscow was founded in 1147, making it over 870 years old.
The city experiences long, cold winters with temperatures often below freezing.

clues: This city is home to the CN Tower, once the world's tallest free-standing structure.

trivia: Toronto hosts the Toronto International Film Festival (TIFF) annually.

clues: This city boasts the world's tallest building, the Burj Khalifa.

clues: This city is famous for its vibrant street markets floating on water.

clues: This city was built on the ruins of an ancient Aztec capital called Tenochtitlán.

fun_fact: Baku’s name may mean ‘city of winds’ for its breezy climate.

trivia: Dolma, stuffed grape leaves, is a traditional dish.
The Maiden Tower is a mysterious 12th-century landmark.

clues: This city is a high-altitude capital near an active volcano.
Known for its colonial churches and a middle-of-the-world monument.
fun_fact: Quito sits at 2,850 meters, one of the highest capitals.
The city’s historic center is a UNESCO site with 40 churches.
trivia: Locro, a potato soup, is a hearty local dish.
The Mitad del Mundo marks the equator line.

clues: This city is the last divided capital in Europe.
Known for its Venetian walls and narrow market streets.
fun_fact: Nicosia’s Green Line splits the city into Greek and Turkish zones.
The city’s walls form a perfect star shape from above.
trivia: Halloumi cheese is grilled to perfection here.
The Büyük Han is a restored Ottoman inn.

clues: This city is a planned capital with lush green parks.
Known for a mosque with minarets like tent pegs.
fun_fact: Islamabad’s Faisal Mosque is one of the largest in the world.
The city was built in the 1960s to replace Karachi.
trivia: Biryani, spiced rice with meat, is a local favorite.
Margalla Hills offer hiking trails with city views.

clues: This city is known for its baroque churches and cobblestone streets.
Home to a hilltop castle and a quirky artist republic.
fun_fact: Vilnius’ Užupis district declared itself a micronation with a constitution.
The city’s cathedral has a secret underground crypt.
trivia: Cepelinai, potato dumplings, are a national dish.
The Gate of Dawn is a revered pilgrimage site.

clues: This city is a futuristic capital with a golden tower.
Known for its extreme winters and a tent-shaped mall.
fun_fact: Astana’s Bayterek Tower symbolizes a Kazakh legend of a golden egg.
The city was renamed Nur-Sultan, then back to Astana.
trivia: Beshbarmak, a meat and noodle dish, is a staple.
The Palace of Peace and Reconciliation is a glass pyramid.

clues: This city is a coastal capital with a royal mausoleum.
Known for its ancient kasbah and blue-painted streets.
fun_fact: Rabat’s Kasbah of the Udayas is a UNESCO site with ocean views.
The city’s name means ‘fortified place’ in Arabic.
trivia: Tagine, a slow-cooked stew, is a culinary star.
The Hassan Tower is an unfinished 12th-century minaret.

clues: This city is older than Rome, with a pink stone skyline.
Known for its brandy and a cascade monument.
fun_fact: Yerevan’s pink tuff stone gives the city a unique glow.
The city claims to be one of the oldest continuously inhabited.
trivia: Lavash, a thin flatbread, is UNESCO-recognized.
Mount Ararat, though in Turkey, dominates the skyline.
